the thing is there would be other products that could claim ownership of RSS -- like Google Reader, which still controls the market almost 10 years after its demise.

and twitter, by not supporting RSS is also a big definer of RSS, in a negative way.

i think we'll be on solid ground once RSS defines itself and the products get out of the way.

And get yourself out to a dark place to enjoy the sky! Light pollution map here: https://www.cleardarksky.com/maps/lp/large_light_pollution_map.html

If you are out there more than 2 hours after sunset or more than 2 hours before sunrise, almost none of the satellites will be visible, so enjoy that dark time. That's what I'm holding on to.

#SaveTheNightSky

title: NASA’s Webb Confirms Its First Exoplanet

last_post.content:
So what have I been up to? Confirming the existence of a planet that is 99% the size of Earth and searching for its atmosphere!

This planet is about 300 degrees Celsius and tidally locked to it star (one side in perpetual daylight), so not exactly habitable for life as we know it 🥵

We don't clearly detect an atmosphere (expected, we don't have all our data yet!) but we also can't rule an atmosphere out at this point! 🪐🔭

https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2023/nasa-s-webb-confirms-its-first-exoplanet

#Astrodon #JWST #Science #Exoplanets

title: Do journals need societies, and do societies need journals?

last_post.content:
I've been having fun thinking about the lessons 350 yrs of Royal Society journal publishing... not so much for journals (or their finances), but for the relationship between societies and journals.

I started off assuming that I would be writing about why learned societies remain the ideal forms of organisation to support journals... but I ended up somewhere slight different.

See: https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/impactofsocialsciences/2023/01/11/do-journals-need-societies-and-do-societies-need-journals/

#journals #ScholarlySocieties #ScholarlyCommunication

NEW: I analyzed the length of proceedings before the German Constitutional Court (BVerfG) for decisions published in the years 1998 to 2022.

⏰ 44 decisions rendered after 10+ years

title: GitHub - beyarkay/eskom-calendar: Get your loadshedding schedule in your calendar and never be left in the dark! Open-source, up-to-date, and developer friendly.

last_post.content:
It’s easy to forget the much of the world doesn’t have Gigabit internet (I don’t!), stable power during the day, even running water, let alone a brand new McComputer every year (not me either).

https://github.com/beyarkay/eskom-calendar is a load shedding info service for South Africa - find out when power is reduced or out in your area and stop/save your work before it’s too late.

A salutary reminder to bloated web & electron apps filled with surveillance capitalism click trackers assuming unlimited resources.

title: The reproducibility issues that haunt health-care AI

last_post.content:
Some of the best-performing AI algorithms for interpreting CT scans are, when re-tested, no better than coin flips.

New Early Access website is up which shows our current roadmap. It’s not a comprehensive list, but it will give you an idea of where our main focus is. We will update the list as we go.

Tomorrow is my first day of class this semester at Duke University.

For my first year seminar I am asking the students to build and use an astrolabe. It is a great way to both get a physical understanding of the sky, and to really appreciate the sophistication of early astronomy.

The astrolabe was used for centuries to tell the time, navigate, etc. Now you can make and use one too by following the instructions here:

https://in-the-sky.org/astrolabe/index.php

#astronomy #astrodon #histodons #teaching

title: Opinion | Republicans and Democrats, Unite Against Big Tech Abuses

last_post.content:
Biden: "Republicans and Democrats, Unite Against Big Tech Abuses"

“First, we need serious federal protections for Americans’ privacy. That means clear limits on how companies can collect, use and share highly personal data—your internet history, your personal communications, your location, and your health, genetic and biometric data. It’s not enough for companies to disclose what data they’re collecting. Much of that data shouldn’t be collected in the first place.”

https://www.wsj.com/articles/unite-against-big-tech-abuses-social-media-privacy-competition-antitrust-children-algorithm-11673439411?mod=hp_opin_pos_3#cxrecs_s

The @DecentSocial #unconference is for those building decentralized social networks across a number of different protocols, coming up on Feb 11th.

It will be online only and cover timezones around the globe.

More details on the website https://decentsocial.net -- please do use the #DecentSocial tag to follow along, suggest topics, and help plan the unconference.

https://elk.zone/ is a *very* nice looking Mastodon web interface that would feel very familiar to any Twitter web user. It's not a new server - you sign in to your existing server with it (it behaves like any other client).

Updated http://pfch.nyc with new class project from last semester.

The course is "Programming for Cultural Heritage" I teach at Pratt Institute which is mostly MILS students learning to work with data programmatically.
A lot of them go from zero coding experience to a complete project by the end of the semester. A lot of interesting project ideas.

title: Gootkit malware abuses VLC to infect healthcare orgs with Cobalt Strike

last_post.content:
The Gootkit loader malware operators are running a new SEO poisoning campaign that abuses VLC Media Player to infect Australian healthcare entities with Cobalt Strike beacons.

https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/gootkit-malware-abuses-vlc-to-infect-healthcare-orgs-with-cobalt-strike/

Sadly Pinafore is being abandoned, but there's a new web client under development that I like even more: http://elk.zone

If Pinafore was like Twitter ~2008, Elk is like Twitter ~2018 after it got loads of quality-of-life improvements, and before they did a bunch of stupid nonsense.

Startlingly good for an alpha version. Can't wait for it to be open sourced - and they're working on a native version in Rust!

title: Why NASA and federal agencies are declaring this the Year of Open Science

last_post.content: Why NASA and federal agencies are declaring this the Year of Open Science https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-00019-y @ChelleGentemann

Science has a replication problem. Should funding be shifted to address this?

"you could put your money into 100 psychology experiments. At the end of the day, you’d have produced a large stack of papers, some of which might be important, and some of which might even be true."

Whereas funding 100 replication experiments would "impact tens of thousands of subsequent papers by creating momentum for improved standards in the field."

https://ssir.org/articles/entry/why_funders_should_go_meta
#OpenScience #Science @academicchatter

title: Russian Flights being informed about Canada's Airspace Ban

last_post.content:
@scott_bot while I am at it here is a memorable example of NOTAMs in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X_KvP8XR30w

This is when lots of countries closed their airspaces to Russian aircraft abruptly following the invasion of Ukraine. Naturally, some Russian aircraft were _in the air_ at that time! The NOTAM system is how you push out breaking changes affecting airspace, so that's how they heard. The video is ATC communicating with Russian pilots. The professionalism and mutual helpfulness in the conversation both inspires me and breaks my heart.

title: A Litany for Survival by Audre Lorde | Poetry Foundation

last_post.content:
Morning #poetry

and when we speak we are afraid
our words will not be heard
nor welcomed
but when we are silent
we are still afraid

So it is better to speak
remembering
we were never meant to survive.

Audre Lorde, "A Litany for Survival"
https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/147275/a-litany-for-survival

#neuroscience #preprint

A new study looking into somatostatin-expressing neurons in the mouse VTA has emerged from our lab, available as a preprint on bioRxiv:
https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.01.06.522982

The study - led by my great colleagues Elina Nagaeva and Annika Schäfer - is straight continuation on Elina's eralier work published in @eLife in 2020 where molecular and electrophysiological properties of somatostatin-expressing cells of mouse VTA were charaterized (available here https://doi.org/10.7554/eLife.59328).

In the current preprint we went on to try to see what those neurons do.

#neuroscience #preprint

A new study looking into somatostatin-expressing neurons in the mouse VTA has emerged from our lab, available as a preprint on bioRxiv:
https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.01.06.522982

The study - led by my great colleagues Elina Nagaeva and Annika Schäfer - is straight continuation on Elina's eralier work published in @eLife in 2020 where molecular and electrophysiological properties of somatostatin-expressing cells of mouse VTA were charaterized (available here https://doi.org/10.7554/eLife.59328).

In the current preprint we went on to try to see what those neurons do.

title: Opinion | I’m a Scientist Who Spoke Up About Climate Change. My Employer Fired Me.

last_post.content:
I've been talking about the shift towards more confrontational #protest tactics in #climate #activism for some time (and the likely response by law enforcement and beyond).

I never imagined that participating in a banner drop at a scientific meeting could have such a professional consequence. The experience of @ultracricket should be a wake up call. @ScientistRebellion @S4F @ClimateHuman

Full piece here: https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/10/opinion/scientist-fired-climate-change-activism.html

OpenAI much in the news just now. Thanks to topicality, two really interesting articles showed up in my inbox this morning. They're pretty good together, shaken, not stirred:

title: The Fundamental Right to Education and Science: Constitutional Law vs Copyright Law - LIBER Europe

last_post.content:
1/ The Finnish parliament rejected draft legislation to expand the exclusive rights of publishers and limit text mining. The committee said the draft would violate the rights to education and science spelled out in the Finnish Constitution and EU treaties.
https://libereurope.eu/article/the-fundamental-right-to-education-and-science-constitutional-law-v-copyright-law/

#Finland #Copyright #TDM

🧵

Today's #arXivsummary: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03628 by Yi et. al. Authors show that a second fractional quantum Hall state exists in the nontrivial, nonabelian fractional quantum Hall liquid phase of a magnetic Weyl semimetal. Implies a gapless phase; may be seen as a generalization of the duality between noninteracting 2D Dirac fermions and QED_3 to 3+1 dimensions. #CondMat #StrEl #arXiv_2301_03628

title: A Profession, If You Can Keep It

last_post.content:
If you want to understand the incredible disjuncture between the old guard of historians and those on the front lines seriously seeking to stop the collapse of the profession, read this account of outgoing AHA president James Sweet's speech https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/08/arts/american-historical-association-james-sweet.html

and then @erin_bartram's talk
https://contingentmagazine.org/2023/01/07/a-profession-if-you-can-keep-it/

Many (not all) tenured senior profs are apparently content to keep debating methodology while the profession burns. It isn't just professionally irresponsible; it's unethical. The luxury of being able to have those debates is enabled by inequitable labor conditions and a failure to take responsibility for training grad students for nonexistent jobs.

#histodons #AHA23

title: [PRE REVIEW]: MultilayerGraphs.jl: Multilayer Network Science in Julia · Issue #5055 · openjournals/joss-reviews

last_post.content:
We have submitted the MultilayerGraphs.jl paper to #JOSS.

Up until now we have been invited by the editors to:

1. Shorten the paper;
2. Remove code from the paper and just link to the “example” folder;
3. Add a few graphical illustrations to explain the chosen keywords.

Here you can follow the open review process https://github.com/openjournals/joss-reviews/issues/5055.

#FOSS #OpenReview #JuliaLang

I don't know how I missed the band Polyphia, which has been massively popular since 2016. On the other hand I only recently got into Guillaume Dufay, who has been massively popular since 1428.

Polyphia takes pop music and cranks up the guitar and drum virtuosity to insane levels, creating gnarly yet still catchy confections. For both the good and bad sides of this, try "Playing God":

title: Fast Robust Predicates for Computational Geometry

last_post.content:
@b0rk and somewhat related to "weird video game bugs" there's a whole class of floating point algorithms where they store numbers as arbitrary precision floating point values

http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~quake/robust.html

as well, arbitrary precision exact arithmetic is very slow, simple floats is very inexact, but you can implement one with the other to have your cake and eat it
